_prev_prog_3.Description: The Mont Belvieu South Rail Terminal has a fourteen point safety management and accident prevention system that is in full compliance with the OSHA Process Safety Management regulation and the EPA Risk Management Program regulation.  The plan is designed to insure the safe design, operation, maintenance and modification of the rail terminal facility.  More details on the safety management / accident prevention program are contained in the Executive Summary.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Enterprise Products Operating, LLC
Mont Belvieu South Rail Terminal


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Enterprise, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of our emergency response program
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Enterprise's Mont Belvieu South Rail Terminal is used to receive a Propane/Propylene mixture (P/P mix) in rail cars and to transfer this mixture via pipeline to Enterprise's Propylene Splitter III.  The Propane/Propylene mixture is received via rail tank cars.  The mixture is unloaded from the tank cars into one of two mixture surge tank which serve as a feed liquid supply to pipeline pumps and a transfer pipeline which ship the offloaded mixture to a fractionation unit that separates the Propane from the Propylene via distillation.  Currently, there are no toxic substances used, manufactured, or stored at the South Rail Terminal that meet the RMP threshold quantities promulgated for those substa

nces. 

Flammables

The South Rail Terminal handles a Propane/Propylene mixture.  Our accidental release prevention program and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.

KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario:


Toxic Substances

As stated previously, no toxic substances were identified at Enterprise's South Rail Terminal as meeting the criteria or threshold limits of the RMP Rule.  Hence, there was no need to conduct a worst-case scenario (WCS) with respect to toxic substances. 

Worst-Case Release Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The WCS associated with a release of flammable materials from Enterprise's South Rail Terminal involves the rupture or failure of one of the two Propane/Propylene mixture surge tanks.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this scenario were to occur.  All Emergency Response protocols would be in effect.  There would be no offsite environmental impact in this scenario due to the material being consumed on site.  Further details on the South Rail Terminal worst case scenario are contained in the Risk Management Program registration document.

Alternative Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This scenario would be mitigated by means of excess flow devices and activation of the emergency response team.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergen

cy response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.  Further details on the alternate case scenario are contained in the Risk Management Program registration document.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMIAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, pro-active approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management Systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As part of our prevention efforts, we have a multitude of programs in which our employees participate.  We have a training program in which the Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the plant, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  We train, use and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.

We have an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies in the process equipment prior to any incident.

Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is detected, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

Records are maintained for all significant accidental releases of hazardous chemicals that occur at the facility.  For each of these incidents (as defined by OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard), formal incident investigations are conducted to identify and correct the root causes of the events.  T

here have been no RMP-defined accidental releases of hazardous material from Enterprise's Mont Belvieu South Rail Terminal within the last five years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Mutual Aid Mont Belvieu group, which includes the Mont Belvieu Police, fire department, and Emergency Medical Service as well as the Chambers County Emergency Management system.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Enterprise personnel are continuously reviewing and improving our PSM systems, especially in the areas of operating procedures and training programs.  Employees are encouraged to submit suggestions or recommendations to improve process or unit operating safety.  All suggestions are reviewed and, if a probable safety improvement can be expected, the suggestion is implemented.  The following projects or programs are currently being installed or re-evaluated to improve safety of the South Rail Terminal facility:

*  The accident prevention program / Process Safety Management system is currently undergoing a complete review and update of all fourteen sections of the program.
*  The company is currently completing a project begun by the former owner to replace older equipment with newer and larger equipment.  Part of this project involves the installation of a maintenance flare to reduce flammable emissions.  Enterprise is evaluating the design of the maintenance flare system to determine if it can be used or revised for continuous use as an operations release flare.
*  The current expansion and modification project has been subjected to a Process Hazard Analysis to minimize the hazards of the liquid transfer o
perations.  Safety recommendations from the Process Hazard Analysis are being installed as part of the rail terminal expansion and upgrade project.
